div.p: TOTENHAM COVRT. A PLEASANT COMEDIE: Acted in the YEARE MDCXXXIII. At the private House in Salisbury-Court.
AT LONDON, Printed by RICHARD OW●●●N, for CHARLES GREENE; and are to be sold at the Signe of the White Lyon, in P à 〈◊〉 Church-yard.

div.head: TO THE WORSHIPFVLL WILLIAM MILLS, Esquire.
div.p:
THough I know your affection to things of this kind is not such, that you covet mens notice of it, I am bold to prefixe your Name to this, as a publike declaration of the gratitude I owe you. If you vouchsafe the reading of it, you will find (after the light title) a light subiect, more gravely drest then the vulgar perhaps expected: who please their senses oftner with showes, then their intellects
with the true morall end of Playes, instruction. That you should authorize it after the Stages tryall was not my intention (for you are none of those that glory to be thought judicious this way, your studies and imployments being more high and serious) but that in your acceptance of it, you would shew your selfe pleased with such acknowledgements as can bee rendered by

div.head: The PROLOGVE.
div.l: Y'Are welcome Gentlemen to Tot'nam-Court,
Where You (perhaps) expect some lusty sport;
Such as rude Custome doth beget in MAY,
When straggling Numbers court that joviall day
With early Riot. No such thing must be
The Subject of our easie COMEDIE.
What then! a humorous, fiery, red-fac'd Host,
That will discourse his Guest into more cost
Then's Cheere is worth: and lyes with so much credit,
As if 'twere Truths Authoritie, He se'd it,
Nor this! The AVTHOR surely then intends
Some Gowne-man of the Towne, that dayly spends
A thrifty Penny, to preserve his Lungs,
For a full Voyce 'midst the contentious throngs.
But heere is no such Satyre: nor is't fit
Abuse should bee the exercise of Wit.
To feast your sense and minds for Cakes and Ale,
New, and not stal'd with handling, heere's a Tale
Drest up of a faire Milke-maid; whose chast Theame
Shall close your stomacks up instead of Creame.
Cook'ry and Wit are like: the selfe same Meat
Delights one's tast, another cannot eat.
So 'tis in Fancie's Worke: this loves a jest;
That Language; Matter pleaseth t'other best.
Our PLAY''s not larded with great store of these:
And how the relish of their salt will please
'Tis doubtfull. Yet We are the lesse affraid;
Because Your Reck'ning is before-hand paid.

div.head: The PERSONS.

list.item: Her Vncle. An angry countrey gentleman.
CICELEY. Sister to Worth-good, but unknowne.
STITCHWELL. A Taylor of the Strand.
IAMES. A wild young gentleman of the Innes of Court.
SAM. A fine Gentleman of the Innes of Court, and Brother to BELLAMIE.

div.p: THE SCOENE, TOTENHAM-COVRT, and the fields about is.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter WORTHGOOD and BELLAMIE, as travailing together before day.

sp.speaker: WORTHGOOD.
sp.l: COme, my Delight; let not such painted griefes
Presse downe thy soule: the darknesse but presents
Shadowes of feare, which should secure us best From danger of pursuit.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Would it were day:
My apprehension is so full of horrour,
I thinke each sound the ayre's light motion
Makes in these thickets, is my Vncles voyce,
Threatning our ruines.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Let his rage persist
To enterprise a vengeance; wee'l prevent it.
Wrap't in the armes of night (that favours Lovers)
We hitherto have scap'd his eager search,
And are arriv'd neere London. Sure I heare
The Bridges Catarracts, and such like murmures
As night and sleepe yeeld from a populous number.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: But when will it be day? the light hath comfort.
〈…〉 senses being lost,
The last are lesse delighted.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Th'early Cocke
Hath sung his summons to the dayes approach:
'Twill instantly appeare. Why, startled Bellamie!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Did no amazing sounds arrive your eare?
Pray listen.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Come, come; 'Tis thy feare suggest's
Illusive fancies: under Loves protection
We may presume of safetie.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow. She startles from him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay me, 'tis sure mine Vncle. Deare Love. Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Astonishment hath seiz'd my faculties.
My Love, my Bellamie. Ha!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Dost thou forsake me Worthgood?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Where's my Love?
Dart from thy silver Crescent one faire beame
Through this black ayre thou Governesse of night,
To shew me whither she is led by feare.
Thou envious darknesse to assist us hither,
And now prove fatall.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Silence your noyse, ye clamorous ministers
Of this injustice. Bellamie is lost;
Shee's lost to me. Nor her fierce Vncles rage
Who whets your eagre aptnes to pursue me
With threats or promises; nor his painted terrors
Of lawes severity, could ever worke
Vpon the temper of my resolute soule,
To soften't into feare, till she was lost: Hollow within.
Not all th'illusive horrors which the night
Presents unto th'imagination
T'affright a guilty conscience, could possesse me,
Whilst I possest my Love: the dismall shrieks
Of fatall Owles, and groanes of dying Mandrakes,
Whilst her soft palme warm'd mine, were musicke to me,
And were this hand but once more clasp't in hers,
This should resist th'assault, inspir'd by love
With more then humane vigour.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Their light appeare's. No safety doth consist
In passion or complaints. Night, let thine armes
Againe receive me; and if no kinde minister
Of better fate guide me to Bellamie;
Be thou eternall.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.

div.head: Scoene. 2.
div.stage: Enter Vncle, servants and tenants with lights, as pursuing them.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Come, wing your hasts: I'le sweeten all your labours
With large rewards: doe but recover them,
I'le ease your rents; exact no costly customes;
Quarrell no more about your commons title.
Good neighbours forward: London's not farre off.

sp.speaker: 1 Ten.
sp.p: 'Tis so farre off, that I cannot see it.

sp.speaker: Vncle.
sp.p: The day will soone discover it.

sp.speaker: 2 Ten.
sp.l: That day is sure a notable informer; yet I believe
He spyes more bad then he mends.

sp.speaker: Vncle.
sp.p: Come, follow me this way.

sp.speaker: 1 Ten.
sp.p: Yes, we will follow; but at some wiser distance: Stay neighbour let him goe. Shall wee rob our carcasses of sleepe all night, that have beene sufficiently tyr'd with the dayes toyles, for his reward? what will that bethinke you? a Christmas dinner; with a Chine of his great Oxe that dy'd at watering of the blayne.

sp.speaker: 2 Ten.
sp.l: You say well neighbour:
And a stale hare with a great pudding in her belly.

sp.speaker: 1 Ten.
sp.p: And the discourse of his Worships hunting her: how many doubles shee made, and mock't his Worships hope of a better dinner so long, till hee thought in his conference she was a Lancashire Witch.

sp.speaker: 2 Ten
sp.p: Yes neighbour, and a choller of Brawne that was fatten'd with stale porredge.

sp.speaker: 1 Ten.
sp.p: And a goose that broke her necke, creeping through the hedge into the Parsons stubble.

sp.speaker: 2 Ten.
sp.p: No neighbour, let the young couple goe, and much joy go with them. Let us take up our rests in this thicket, or the next house; for I am as sleepy as if I had eaten a Puppie.

sp.speaker: 1 Ten.
sp.p: How, eat a Puppie!

sp.speaker: 2 Ten.
sp.p: Yes, a Puppie; I heard our Landlords Carter speake it last Whitsontide in a Play.

sp.speaker: 1 Ten.
sp.p: And I am as drousie as a Constable at midnight.

sp.speaker: 2 Ten.
sp.p: Why then resolv'd: 'twill be day presently: let's put ont the candle, and go to bed, and farewel Landlord. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: The day begins to breake; and trembling light
As if affrighted with this nights disaster,
Steales through the farthest ayre, and by degrees
Salutes my weary longings. Yet 'tis welcome,
Though it betray me to the worst of fate
Love and desire e're suffer'd. Oh my Worthgood,
Thy presence would have check't these passions;
And shot delight through all the mists of sadnesse,
To guide my feare safe through the paths of danger:
But thou art lost, and all my joyes are fled
Not to returne without thee.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: New feares assault me. 'Tis a womans voyce.
She sings; and in her musicks cheerefulnesse
Seemes to expresse the freedome of a heart
Not chain'd to any passions. Be propitious
Thou regent o're my fate, and guide her hither
Vnto my comfort.

div.head: The SONG within.
div.l: What a dainty life the milke-maid leads?
When over the flowry meades
She dabbles in the dewe,
And sings to her Cowe;
And feeles not the paine
Of love or disdaine.
She sleepes in the night, though she toyles in the day;
And merrily passeth her time away.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: What a blest state is this? the minds content
Sweeten's all sufferings of th'afflicted sense.
Those that are bred in labour thinke it sport
Aboue the soft delights which wanton appetite
Begets for others, whom indulgent fortune
Prefers in her degrees; though equall nature
Made all alike. Oh, might I change my misery
For such a shape of quiet.

div.head: The fourth Scoene.
To her CICELEY, as going to milking.
div.l: She comes this way.
He venture to accost her.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Ha! what silken butterfly's yonder! Shee looks not like one that had kept her selfe warme all night at the Brick-kils: yet silke petticoates many times are glad with worse lodging.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Good morrow maid.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Should I salute you so, 'twould bring my wit in question. Pray you what are you?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: A distrest maid.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: A maid at your years, and so neere London; where the state of one at 15. is as rate as a light wenches conversion. Never an early walking gallant to take you up this morning! The Parke here hath fine conveniences: or Totenham Court's close by: Tis suspected that fine Citie Ladies give away fine things to Court Lords for a Countrey Banquet there.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I cannot construe it; my innocence makes understanding uselesse. Good mayd, wife or widdow (for sure you are a woman) doe a courteous office to your sexe in me, and guide me to London.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: It seems you are a kinde Countrey Gentlewoman, that have bestow'd your Maidenhead on your Fathers servingman, and are come up to have a Citizen foder your broken ware. The pollicie is growne stale: 'twould hardly take ever since the Ballad curst the Carrier that brought her to towne.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Y'are a bad woman sure: and from th'aboundance of you owne foule ils suspect all others.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: The to, is angry, it would faine counterfeit something: perhaps to insinuate her selfe, and make me her agent. But you are deceiv'd my pretty morsell of wantonnesse; my selfe and my Milke-paile are both honest: I have no disguis'd tone of Come, or three penny thrip to cloake a procuresse. I am not the Blades intelligence whether Franke or Moll remove their lodgings to scape the Constables search and Bridewell. I will to my Cowes, and leave you to the fate of the morning: despaire not of a customer; but be sure I catch you not napping; for if I doe, I have lesse mercy then Prentices at Shrovetide. I hate hedge-coupling worse then fasting at Christmas, or a Puritans long Grace over short Commons.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: If you are good, pray stay and comfort me.
The sense of my 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Why let but an honest 〈…〉 in Middlesex) finde you not guilty of any thing that may make compassion deafe— alas, she sownes; poore gentlewoman, bee comforted. Should shee miscarry, I were in danger, having no witnesse to purge the suspition of being her murderesse.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Worthgood farewell.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Ha! what said she? Worthgood! I have heard my Father often speake that name, and sigh after it. Alas, she is dead; her breath scarce moves.

div.head: The fifth Scoene.
To them Keeper and Slip.
div.p: Oh Father, you are come in time to see me undone: I met this Gentlewoman as I was going to milking, and shee is fallen dead. I shall be questioned.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Why what is she?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Nay that's as hard to tell, as the successe of my danger. She nam'd one Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That word strike's deepe amazement. Is shee quite dead!

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Dead as a herring Sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: And are not you in a pickle Cicely? She is not dead Sir; she breathes.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: She may be recover'd. Pull her by the nose.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Pull it off: no matter for spoyling her face if shee be dead.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Wring her by the little finger.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Her little finger is ring'd; and I will wring it from her.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: No robbing the dead Slip.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why should the dead partake of living ceremonies?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Cast water on her face.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Blow winde in her face. Can water make one alive that's dead? unlesse it be hot water.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Her spirits are return'd; give her more ayre.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: A womans spirits? they are divellish sure: I had best conjure them backe againe.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Where am I! what a pleasant vision
Pleas'd my dead slumbers, and presented joyes.
As I was passing through th'eternall shades
Towards Elisium, one of fates Ministers
Told me I should returne; and this same day
Enjoy my Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: What's he should own that name! wonder and doubt
Have rais'd a warre within me, Looke up mistris:
You shall not want what comfort we can give you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Defend me gentle powers: yet yee shall never
O'retake my heart: thats still with Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: For some blest Oracle to unfold the meaning
Of this so oft repeated name.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Ere you returne me to my angry Vncle.
My soule shall flie and meet with his embraces.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: What meane you gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You are murderers
Of that content in me goodnesse would cherish▪
You serve the purposes of a passionate man
For base reward; and that shall render you
Base to opinion.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Pray sir, let mee conjure downe this Divell in her tongue; 'twill raise tempests else. Murderers, and base! Pray Gentlewoman, to whom speake you all this?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: To you, the injurers of my true love
And Worthgoods.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Mistris, we know you not; and all your words
Appeare distraction: Nor can they satisfie
Our yet amazement.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: If you are not such
As my too fearefull apprehension thought you,
Pray, what are ye?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Such as doe compassionate
Your feeling sorrowes, and would comfort you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You'l then performe an act of piety
Worthy record. Since my distresse hath made me
The object of your pitty; pray conduct me
To some neere house, for I am wondrous faint.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Goe home with her daughter; use your best care in administring to her: we know not what fate depends upon it. When I have walkt the round I'le returne. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: But pray Ciceley, withall, neglect not my breakfast. Rising early and walking gets us good stomacks: yet I could be content to fast with such lac'd mutton and a good cullice more then halfe a morning.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: What passions fight within me, that beget
Severall constructions of this accident?
But what my hope interprets cannot be.
How apt is misery to dreame that blessings
Are all immediate, and no underworkings
Of meanes and counsell! I'le not flatter it;
(Tis but th'effect of passion) but returne
To my delight of labour. Saw you the heard
Last night sirrah?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: And how fed they?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: With their mouthes.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You'l not leave your sawcie wit, untill it be beaten out of you.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'T would be but sawcily done of it to leave me so: but if it wil not keepe me from beating, I'le keepe it no longer; but be mannerly. The deare fed well sir, onely a mischance. Some Cuckolds curre (for I saw him run towards London) had pull'd downe two or three young deare.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: And what did you with them?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
I sent a Fawne to a wanting poet, a friend of mine; who I presume will make profitable use of it. Dresse it in
some lamentable epitaph and dedicate to his ningle: whose compassion to bounty must redeeme his lavender'd plush, and commend him againe to converse with sacke and good company.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You have surely glean'd from that Poet.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Somthing to make people laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Venus did you with the rest?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: A longing Lady in the strand had a pricket. Then I sent a soare to Barber-Surgeons Hall. A little soare makes them a great feast.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Well sirrah, round you the south side oth' Parke; and meet me at the great Oake. I'le this way.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Pray stay sir, who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Hee seemes a discontented Gentleman. Some dueller perhaps.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Some hot spur'd Gallant, that got a drunken feaver last night, and must bleed this morning.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Perhaps to revenge an affront done his Mistris.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: His common Mistris you meane sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: It needs no adjective the sense is common enough.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: So is the creature; a Cart take them. They have infected more honest Alehouses with bad names, then Cakes and Creame will ever restore againe. A wench is growne a necessary appendix to two pots at Totenham Court.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: To your walke sirrah. I'le observe him.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: And I'le home to observe how I can sleepe after early rising. If my master should catch me napping, 'tis but dreaming a lie to excuse it. I'le perswade him 'tis as true Prophecie as Bookers Almanacke. Exit.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: After so many longings to salute
The welcome light, it hath betray'd my sense
To worse affliction, then if sights privation
Had made it uselesse; since it wants the object
Can both delight and feed it, Back blushing morne
To thy Mygdonian bed; there shake the dew
From thy wet locks; and teach thy guilty shame
To dye that red in an eternall black,
Vnlesse it bring more comfort.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Discontent
Rides on his forehead; and doth seeme to trample
Vpon his soules dejection. Would I knew him.
Good morrow Sir.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Ha! tis a faire salute.
I doe returne your wish.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Sir, you must pardon me
If I seeme curious in some few demands.
My office and this place are priviledge
For more then questions. Pray Sir what are you?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: This sure is Marrowbone-Parke, and he the Keeper.
A Gentleman that comes not to offend you.
I spoyle no game: you see I am unfurnish'd
Of instruments for such a wanton mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: But Sir, without a better satisfaction
I must suspect you still. Mere recreation
To walke for health seldome invites young Gallants
To leave their beds so early. I must have more.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Must sawcie groome! can any patience
Conster it manners? Your rude compulsion shall not
Enforce me to expresse so weake a spirit,
Whilst I have hands, and this.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: At that guard Sir?
Then this must countercheck it. Either tell me
Your name, condition, and your busines here;
By my just anger for this foule provoking
I shall not spare you else.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: How happie now
Might this occasion make me, were she lost
Beyond that hope which whispers her yet safety!
I must preserve my selfe. Yet if thou triumph'st
In my submission, 'cause I had rather lose
A little outward credit to prevent
Worse mischiefe, know I can devise revenge,
Shall be a faire example for base difference
From the pretence of any borrowed power
To overdoe it's duty. My name's Worthgood.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Enough; that word hath power to check the force
Of any passion, though the hottest rage
Enflam'd it to be active.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Heer's a change.
Why sure my name's a spell. How it hath calm'd
The tempest of his fury!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: What black starre
Was found th'ascendant in my crooked birth:
That all my lifes sad accidents should be
Such pregnant ils begetting one another!
One suddaine rashnesse in a moment might
Perhaps have min'd him my dutie honours:
Making this hand a mover to his death,
Whose life I ought to cherish.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: What would'st else?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Nothing but pardon Sir; or if you please
Th'occasion brought you hither. Lost you no company?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: It cannot sure be feare that makes me jealous.
I dare the worst of fate. Be he an actor
In my pursute, I'le venture all at once.
I have lost a Gentlewoman, and doubt her safety:
If any chance hath guided you to find her,
Doe not delay my satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I joy that chance made me the instrument
Of such a good. Please you to follow me.
I'le guid you to this pensive one, that grieves
More your fear'd losse then her owne misery.
She nam'd you oft; when (by her fit transported)
Recovering from a sowne, she thought her selfe
Surpriz'd by some that meant her injurie.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Shall I give faith? my resolution's mad;
Yet it shall trye th'event. Despaire may bring
A good successe to an indifferent thing. Exeunt.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter FRANKE and GEORGE, as walking to TOTENHAM-COVET.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.l: FIe Franke; there's such a disproportion,
'Twill nere be brought to an equalitie.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why George, dost think th'exterior goods of fortune,
Or titular greatnesse that derives it selfe
From larger springs, and slow's to swell the blood
With attributes of gentle, or of noble
Can make the difference such, that the free soule
Must have the limits of her large desires
Prescrib'd by them? Nature's impartiall:
And in her worke of man prefer's not names
Of auncestors▪ She sometimes formes a piece
For admiration from the basest earth
That holds a soule: and to a Beggars issue
Gives those perfections make a beauty up;
When purer molds po'ish'd and g'oss'd with titles,
Honours and wealth, bestow upon their bloods
Deform'd impressions; objects onely fit
For sport or pitty.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yet never can the mixture
Of gold with clay make any transformation
Of that base matter into purer metall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The Chymistry of Love can surely doe it.
Wedlocke conferres all honour that's a husbands
Vpon his wife.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: And therefore you will marry
A milke wench; one that's drudge unto necessitie.
'Twould be a credit to that long continuance
Of noble matches which your anncestors
Have link'd to the chaine of their owne bloods,
To make the series of their Families
Spread in so many glorious divisions.
Come, let my counsell guide these passive Fires
To flame aright, and send their Pyramids
More upwards. Let the grosser stuffe that feeds them,
By an inversion, choake them. From advice
Men must choose wives, not passion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: She is faire:
Upon her person all the graces waite,
And dance in rings about her. Her bright eye
Is Loves chiefe mansion where he keepes his Court.
Envy not faire ones, if my fancie doth
Give all your dues to her, save onely those
Which your defects supply from wanton art.
Her white and red she borrow's not from any
Cosmetique drugs; nor puzzles the invention
Of learn'd practitioners for oyle of Talxe
To blanch an Ethiops skin. Lillies and Roses
Are figures fitting common beauties: hers
Wants a comparison but its proper selfe.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You swell her praise too high; so meane a subject fits not these raptures.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Shee's a subject, George,
For larger volumes then invention
Yet ever fill'd with flattering hyperboles.
The very thought of her hath strain'd my heart-strings
Vp to a pitch of joy; whose musicke makes
My spleene dance lusty measures.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: If she be
So rare a piece, her low condition
Makes me suspitious shee's some common wanton
Lurks in that maske for safety.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Did not friendship
Restrain't, I should be angry: nay more; punish
So great a sin against her innocence.
I have laid all the baits that might entice
Apt inclination to sweet wickednesse;
But could not catch her that way. She hath shund them
With witty scorne, and such imperious checks
Have made me blush at my intentions soulenesse:
Which now is cleer'd with noble resolution
To give my hot desires their satisfaction
In faire embraces, such as the reverence
Of lawfull Wedlock sweetens.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Vertuous policie.
Kill reputation, that you may preserve
A little better conscience. Any judgement
Would make a faire construction of my life,
That surfets in delights, and playes the Epicure
In all varietie and choyce of pleasures
Sooner then of thy act. Where ils doe want
A faire excuse (as thine doth) they are doubled.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: When thou hast seene her, thou wilt soone acknowledge
In what a misty error thy invectives
Have lost themselves.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Nay rather hide her from me.
She may raise motions; and if I should rivall thee,
I must be serv'd: nothing was ere devis'd
To fright libidinous nature from it's pronenesse,
That can restraine me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Shal't not make me jealous?
Her soule is guarded with so many vertues
Temptations cannot better it: and i'th' way
Of noble love (though yet she never sung
The musicke of consent) I dare preferre
My selfe the first accepted.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Still be confident.

div.head: The second Scoene.
To them CHANGLOVE, STITCHWELL, and his WIFE.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Some Citie loving couple.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: What's that Gallant?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Surely 'tis Will Changelove;
The Proteus of affection: one that vary's
As many shapes of love as there are objects.
But what that shee-thing is I doe not know.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: She seems a handsome piece. That opportunity
Would play the Bawd a little.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You'd be nibbling.
Changlove is my acquaintance. If they come this way (as 'tis most likely Tottenham-Court's the end of their early walking) I'le be thy introduction. Let's walke softly.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Whilst I doe ruminate some policie.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Besides the recreation Sir, tis healthful.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: Indeed sloth duls the spirits activenesse.
And too much sleeping blunts the senses quicknesse;
Though some be very needfull; their affects
Are the preservers of their instruments.
I love early rising.

sp.speaker: Mris. St.
sp.p: But me thinks a nap in a morning's good.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: True Mris. Stitchwell; when the braine hath purg'd
It selfe of grosser fumes, the fancy yeeld's
Such solace to the inward waking sense
In pleasant dreames, that I have often wish'd
Those shadowes reall which they have presented;
Or their continuance to eternitie.
Indeed I love to sleepe in the morning.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: But stirring and exercise, I say.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would you would vse it in bed then.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: I tell you Mr. Changelove though I am a Taylor I keepe servants that are stout knaves. I love them well, and they looke well to my businesse. On holydayes I give them leave to use exercise.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes husband, your finisher is a pretty a fellow as ever did tradesman or his wife service. He pitcheth the barr, and throws the stone; it doth me good to think of it.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: I have a Cornish-Lad that wrastles well, and hath brought home Rabbets every Bartholmew-tide these five yeares. At stoole ball I have a North-west strippling shall deale with ever a boy in the strand.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Now you speake of a ball, I would wee had one here; tis a commendable exercise: the great Physitian Galen wrote a booke, de exercitations parvae pilae.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What's that, pray sir?

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Concerning the exercise of the little ball.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It seems great Physitians will busie themselves about small things: but they are not of my mind.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: How lik'st the project?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: As the end proves it; howsoever, it promiseth fairely.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: They are arriv'd: let us prepare our selves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mr. Changelove; a happy day follow this pleasant morning.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Worthy friend, I returne your salute with double wishes: pray know this Gentleman and his bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The day must needs bee fortunate, that begins with such faire Omens.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I pray sir, why doth that Gentleman shun your company? I hope we fright him not. It had beene manners to salute me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He alwayes doth that by Attourney Mistris.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Then I must pay the fees.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The truth is, he is a great woman-hater.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now out upon him. I thought he was gelt, hee is so fat. Beast that I was to be so unmercifull to a dumb thing; I had a dog serv'd so for the same purpose.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is a disposition in his will,
Not a defect of power.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: How said you sir? cannot that Gentleman indure women?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Hardly their sight at distance. 'Tis affliction
Vnto his very soule to heare their vertues
Discourst, unlesse in scorne.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: A strange unmanly humour: I love not that.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: May all the curses our injur'd sexe can study, fall upon him for it: and I thinke we can curse.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I know, to him my company is deare;
And our intentions have the selfe same end
Of mutuall enjoying: now, with what dejection
He doth expect I should divide my selfe
From you, may be conceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I beseech you kind sir leave us not.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: I should love some witty plot upon him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: He is my friend: yet I would gladly ayde
In any easie mischiefe, that might ayme
At his reclaiming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let's get him arraign'd as one was in a play. Let me alone to aggravate his inditement to the Jury; which shall be twelve Midwives of my acquaintance: yet Ile be sworne I never us'd any of them.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: I have it.

sp.speaker: Stich.
sp.p: Pray first heare mine: let's run to Totenham-Court for a wager.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent; so his grosse bodies toyle
To follow us, shall be our laughter.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Right: or if he stay behind, let my wife alone to vexe him.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: Let's run then: 'tis a brave Olympicke exercise;
I love it well; but how shall we dispose
Of all these cumbers?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let us not be foot-men.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.l: Indeed a seeming carelesse stay'd formalitie
In such like wantonnesses best becomes
A gentleman. I love it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Forwards then.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: The wager?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Every man his dozen. Exeunt running.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why sweetheart; why husband; why Iohn; doe you leave your Wife behind, to bee taken up by every body? Now the love of mans society defend mee from this abuser of creation. Come not neere mee thou man of clouts; thou maulkin of virilitie; thou halfe woman, and all beast: or with these nayles I will teare out thine eyes, and all the double things are left about thee.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Be milder gentle mistris. There's nothing in me
Appears unto my selfe so full of guilt
It should deserve reproach from you a stranger.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: There's nothing in you indeed sir; your friend hath given me your character. You pretend to hate women, because women have reason to hate you.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I hate women!
Now by my love of pleasure, no delight
Hath any relish on the wanton palat
Of my desires; unlesse some mixture season it
That is deriv'd from them.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes sir; you may take delight in them, but they little in you. Come not too neere, there's infection in it: my blood desires no freezing. The Summer of my youth is not yet halfe spent; or if it were Autumne with mee, high feeding and ease requires something.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: She takes me for an Eunuch. Sure my friend
Hath overdone his part; and drawne the counterfeit
Too neere the life of truth. Sweet Mistris heare
The language of my heart that cannot glosse
My plainer thoughts with superficiall words.
I love you; my desires are throughly fir'd,
And burne my bloud: which but your free enjoying
Nothing can quench.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why, I am a woman sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I thinke you are; and one made up for pleasure,
More then the dull converse of what's defective.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You say true sir: I heare it with a heavy heart.
But I hope sir, you would not have me make my husband a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Fie, that's a grosse construction; onely shame
And common knowledge doth it, not the act
Of a Wifes wantonnesse.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I need no instructions for secrecie. Trust mee a handsome Gentleman. The wickednesse of his friend to beleeve him so. Dare you kisse me sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A pledge for what should follow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You shall doe what you will with me, but making my husband Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: No more of that. Nay, this way.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What, back againe! No by my Strand-honesty. Ile to Totenham-court after my husband. If there be that necessity at any time that I must make my husband a Cuckold, I'le doe it before his face: any Citizens Wife can doe it behind her husbands backe.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Your will disposeth mine: we there may finde
Handsome conveniences; and I'le renew
My counterfeit of woman-hater: it
May cast a mist before his jealous eyes
Would watch us else. Exeunt.

div.head: The third Scoene.
div.stage: Enter CICELEY and BELLAMIE in one anothers clothes.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: I hope y'are satisfied: but to what end this change should serve, I would faine be instructed.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I'le tell you. When we fear'd pursuit, we left our horses, and the high way. The horses are surely found; and by them my being hereabouts may bee conjectur'd. Now this disguise shall helpe me to scape their search.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Now out upon't. Had I no better an opinion of your honestie, then of your wit (both which smell all together of the countrey) I would againe- leave you to seeke out your owne danger. You have gentle-fide mee with your clothes; and you are handsome enough in mine: for though I am but a milke-wench, I ever lov'd neatnesse. Now you shall personate my maid, and wait upon me to London; I'le personate you, and if any thing rise from the mistake, wee'l turne it to the best use. If I finde not out your sweet-heart, let me never be counted a Prophetesse: and I am sure I have foretold weather from the turning up of my Cowes tayle.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Dispose me as you please, I dare the worst
Of my malicious. Now love hath arm'd me
With better resolution.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: In this disguise Ile meet the Gallant courts me every morning at Tottenham-Court, and sound the depth of his pretended honest meaning. My condition is to low to win upon his desires to marry me: and the other thing without it, he shall never have.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Why Ciceley, Ciceley, I say my breakfast A quick supply of meat, drinke and sleepe, or I rage presently.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Blesse me, who's that?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: My fathers man.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Hee'l spoyle all. To them Slipp hastily.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Be you confident.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Where's this Maggoti-pie of Marrowbone? Come you cleane wash't chitterling, and give mee my breakfast. How now Ciceley, where hath your face beene? at the painters? Hay-day; Ciceley's owne face, and this Mistris dye for love Ciceley-side. Now I sweare by hunger (and that's a strong oath) I thinke women have more fegaries then the Divel would have Clients, if he were a Lawyer and pleaded without fees.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Keepe counsell sirrah you had best; and if my father aske for mee, tell him I will not bee lost long. So fare you well. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: You will not bee lost long: hee is likely to have a sweet match of it that finds you. Yet I could be content my seaven yeares service might bee so rewarded. But the baggage is as coy as an Aldermans eldest daughter: shee hath beaten me a hundred times (coward as I was for suffering it) for attempting to kisse her. But now I will revenge it upon her Creame-bowles; over whose sweets I will triumph.

div.head: The fourth Scoene.
To him KEEPER, WORTHGOOD.
div.p: New mischiefe; I am againe delayd. If I forbeare my breakfast but two minutes longer, my guts will shrinke into minikins: which I bequeath the poore Fidlers at Totenham-Court, for a May-dayes Legacie.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Y'are welcome to this roofe; too meane a covering
For such a guest.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Your first sir hath inritch't it.
And hallowed it into a Temple. Pray sir.
Conduct me to the Altar, where I may
Pay the due sacrifice of my desires
To her; and thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Slip, call my daughter.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Which daughter sir? your daughter gentlewoman, or your gentlewoman daughter?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Your trifling's unseasonable sirrah.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why sir, Ciceley's no more plaine Ciceley, but Ciceley in lac't sattin. The gentlewoman and she are run out of themselves one into another.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: But where are they?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: For ought I know, run away one with another.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Run you after, and call them back.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible: who knowes which way they are gone. Besides, 'tis a mist would choake a brewers horse; I cannot see one hand for the other.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Sir, my suspition prompts me you are trecherous:
And these faire seeming undertakings traps
To catch me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Sir, you make a worse construction
Of my good meaning, then so faire expressions
Can any way deserve. Pray sir goe with me,
Wee'l overtake them.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: I will share the paines;
And venture once againe to try you thorowly.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Follow you sirrah. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: A killing command. The best is, it will breake my heart, no matter then for my belly. Hunger, I defie thee; revenge I hugg thee. I will lead you a wild-goose chase, till we come to Toten-ham Court: where I will score two dozen, and reckon with mine hostesse maid, whose belly I have rais'd with umbles. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You are the Olympian, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Doe you thinke Gentlemen I'd let you out-strip me at exercise? I'le jump with ye for a dozen more.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Pray Sir let's jump: I love it mightily.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My breaths not yet recover'd. By this time sir. your Wife hath converted my friend to a civiller disposition.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Let her alone. If she doe it not, I durst forsweare exercise; and that would be the greatest vexation.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Greater then if your maid should drop the candle on your festivall sattin doublet?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Or the Cats pisse upon your Military feather?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Or an inferiour neighbour be prefer'd for a common counsell man?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Meere triales to the forbearing of exercise.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Or if a gallant should deale with your wife in your absence for body covering, and give her Court payment.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: A very likely matter. She that goe's thrice a weeke to morning exercise, and will make repetition over sweet meates at a gossipping. I tell ye gentlemen, I have trusted her to a Maske, and the Innes a Court revelling: she knew the way home agen without a Cryer. She hath converted a hundred of her purer neighbours, by her example.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Heere's more then Citie confidence. But shall we enter?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Y'are welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Chang.,
sp.p: A handsome roome sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: The best in the house sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Your Wife's come, sir.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Welcome sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Kinde gentlemen, hold my heart, oh. Nay one at once: pray hold it hard, oh!

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Whats the matter chucke?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Oh my breath: there's not so much wind left in me, as would make a noise to bee excus'd with the creaking of ones shoo: oh. You are a kinde husband to leave mee
behind. Had it beene with one that had lov'd a woman, shew'd her the neerest way, or laid her down upon his cloake when she had beene weary. But I thinke I fitted him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And beshrew him if he fitted not you.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Here he is likewise.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You blow hard George.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, shall we walke in.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I would enjoy my friend a little heere.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You shall enjoy your friend sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And what successe?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Why dost not heare her promise?
You shall enjoy your friend. Shee's plyant Franke
Vnto my wishes: nothing no remaines
But to deceive her husband; thou must ayd me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Would'st have me Pandarize?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: I'le doo't for thee.
These are sweet sins, and onely doe intend
The pleasure of desire, which would be kill'd
With two much scruple.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What place is this? a common Ale-house?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Feare you nothing, but put on confidence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I have seene that face, the figure's in my heart.
'Tis surely she: her habit cannot mock
My knowing sense. I'le venture on the tryall.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: This is his Milke-maid sure. I still suspected
'Twas some disguis'd name to conceale a Mistris.
Now by my life shee's faire; I envy him;
And my desires have almost tempted me
To put in for a share: but friendship checks it.
Shee may perhaps be vertuous, and well borne.
And worthy his resolves: my Citie beauty
Shall serve at this time.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Didst thou thinke that maske
Could veile thee from my soules distinguishing?
Wherein thy form's imprest, which fancie shews me
At every change of thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Clothes have not alter'd
My person nor condition. I am still
Plaine Ciceley and your hand-maid. This exchange
Proceeds but from an honest merriment:
And when you understand the story right,
You'l make a faire construction.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Twere a sinne
To thinke amisse of thee; teares cannot expiate▪
When thou art mine, I'le feed thy appetite
With pleasures best variety. Taylors dayly
Shall shape proportions for thy dainty body,
To make invention pregnant of new fashions.
Th'Exchange shall be thy Wardrobe to supply
Thy will with choyce of dressings t'hearken out
A jewell to adorne thee, if the value
Exceede not my estate; I'le sell it all
To purchase thy content.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Your promises
Are much too large. My too unworthy service
Cannot deserve to be commanded by you.
Gallant I'le trye you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Th'extasie hath made me
Forget my friend: 'tis shee George chang'd in habit

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I am your servant faire one, and my heart
Vow's an obedience when your commands
Assigne me any taske.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I doe not like
The courtship of these gallants: 'tis grosse flattery,
And tends I feare to ill.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come dearest will you
Accept the entertainment of this place?
Some worthy company within expects me.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: I shall straine modesty, you excusing it.
Come maid.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Why should I feare; that have defence
From Worthgoods love, and mine own innocence? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.p: Y'Are welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Now my parrat of froth, whose mouth is lin'd with tapestry; what company is in the house?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: None of your acquaintance but Mr. Changelove.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Will Changelove? prethee call him hither.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: I shall sir; By and by. Some stew'd pruines for the two costive Citizens in the Buls head; and more rowles for the three Taylors in the Smithfield-Lyon.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: How shall we spend the day Sam? Exit.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Let's home to our studies and put cases.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Hang cases and bookes that are spoyl'd with them. Give me Iohnson and Shakespeare; there's learning for a gentleman. I tell thee Sam, were it not for the dancing-schoole and Play-houses, I would not stay at the Innes of Court for the hopes of a chiefe Iustice-ship.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Time would be better spent in reading lawes,
Teaching our knowledge how to argue doubts:
For in our after-states such may arise
That without policies helpe may ruine it.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p:
Formalitie; a grave youth in a gowne. Thou think'st 'tis becomming to walke thus to Totenham-Court, and at
home so punctuall in conformitie. I had rather a French consumption should weare my hayre off then a round cap.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis not to make it my profession,
(Although in some it be most necessary)
(For how can government and lawes subsist
Without their ministers, whose skill and judgement
Distinguish right from wrong) but to be able
To manage what's mine owne, as time shall send it,
You are likely to inherit faire possessions,
Gain'd by a fathers industry; perhaps
With some contention, and conveyances
May be defective: wer't not better farre
Your selfe could understand it, then to trust
The honesty or skill of a bought counsel?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Hang state: I tooke no paines to get, why then should I take any to keep it? if it will stay, so 'tis: if not, Shop-keepers that will trust, shall be paid when they can get it. A law of necessity Sam, and alwayes in force with Gallants.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I had rather heare another resolution.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Will Changelove, well met at Totenham-Court.
What made thee rise so early?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: The company of halfe a man: expound my Riddle, and be a whole Oedipus.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: It must be more then thy Taylor.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Right, his Wife; who being halfe of himselfe, makes up the third part a halfe man. I love his company man, and pay him with nothing but courtesies: a Totenham-Courts kindnesse is principall, interest and security.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: What shall we drinke? Ale?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I love it best; the old English naturall drinke. But can this gentleman study after Ale?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: If I avoid the excesse.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Ale's muddy: what thinke you of Beere?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: I love Beere best. The planting of hoppes was a rare projection in the Dutch; it hath taught some of them English naturally.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Shall wee hunt to day Will? I heard the common crye abroad.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Hunting! 'tis sport to make immortall activenes
Even in the dullest Earth. A well-mouth'd crye
Out-does the Sphaeres in Musique. Gods themselves
Have left their fabulous Heaven, to put on
The shapes of hunters: courting such delights
In these disguises, that hath made them wish
Th'exchange of their ethereall government
To live with mortalls. I love hunting dearly.
What saith your friend?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Indeed sir, my affection
Is better pleas'd with solitary studie:
A sober mornings walke, is exercise
Enough for me.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: You are to be commended.
Why, Contemplation is the very being
Of Mans delight: it shewes his nobler part
Converse with things divine; the nimble soule
Climbs by it to a height of happinesse.
I must confesse I love it. Musique

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Is there Musique with the company you left?

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: And good too: 'tis company of that curiositie, ordinary stuffe will not please them.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Would thou wouldst enter mee into their acquaintance; we might have a dance.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Why, I love dancing too. Agilitie
Commends the good composure of one's bodie;
And gracefull garbs are taking. No perfection
Doth make the object of a handsome man
So pleasing in a Ladies eye, as Dancing.
This Room's more spacious: I'le invite them hither.

div.head: The third Scoene.
To them FRANKE, CICELEY, STITCHWELL, WIFE, BELLAMIE, and GEORGE behind the women.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The room's possest.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You may command a resignation.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Please you t'admit us; we would faine partake
Your worth and company.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Your friends Will Changelove?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Yes, noble sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: They'r welcome to my knowledge.
Numbers addition will increase our mirth,
And swell it to more height.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Arme me now confidence,
And teach my tongue, that never spake untruth
From a consideration, practise lying,
And the denyall of my proper selfe.
It is my brother, hee'l discover me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis surely she: they'r all her lineaments.
Had I ne're seene her; had not knowing sense
Power to distinguish, naturall instinct
Would tell me 'tis my sister. Why disguis'd?
And why come hither? it hath wrapt my reason
In mists of wonder. Yet I cannot feare
She hath betray'd her honour to base wantonnesse.
She had a guard of vertues; else hypocrisie
Taught her to seeme a Saint, and paint that goodnesse
With a false colour. Know you not my sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: No indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is not your name Bellamuel?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Neither sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Deny's her selfe.
There's something in't above my reach of feare.
Passion forbeare me, and I'le worke with policie,
To find the scope of all.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: A sweet young Gentleman.
Is this your sweet-heart maid?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Is she your servant?
I would have cal'd her kinswoman for resemblance
She hath with one of mine.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Your Aunt or Cousin?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Meanes she in the mysticall sense of ill?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Shall we dance gentlemen? Musicknesse, and let activenesse freeze! Shall I use you sweet Mistris?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Kindly sir, or I am waspish. A waspe you know hath a sting.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Please that grosse gentleman?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By no meanes sir: dancing will hurt his Sciatica.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Doe you know him then?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Yes, and will know him better if he come neere me.
He is one into whom the spirit of Swetnam's crept.
I hope sir you are of a kinder disposition to our sexe.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: You see Mistris I am for their company any way.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Pray sir let's goe neerer the women.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Pray sir forbeare: you'l not compell me rudely.
Perhaps ther's an aversion in my nature.
The company of women's mine affliction.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: My wife shall vexe you then.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: And I love Mans societie: solid soules,
Void of all light impressions; whose discourse
Tends not to superficiall complement,
But hath more sense then sound.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You are for dancing;
Possesse my roome,

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: The womens creature sir.
There's Magick in their company that charmes
All masculine affections, but of pleasure
In their enjoying. I'le spin or threed their needles,
Read Spenser and th' Arcadia for their company.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'le dance with you Mr. Changelove.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: One cup more, Ile be for the exercise.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You'l have more anon husband, then your head will well carry.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: She meanes hornes.
Which if I fayle to give her, may I turne
Chastities convert, and be mortifi'd
From my concupiscence with hourely discipline.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why how now husband? you'l be tippled presently.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Hold good wife, before strangers? T'other dozen, and then I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would you were gone once for me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: So would I.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Gentlemen, a health to—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whom sir?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: All the Cuckolds in the strand.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Fye husband, you forget your selfe. Nay, gentlemen hee is such another man; when hee hath got a cup or two hee'l not stick to abuse his betters. I beseech you beare with him, I shall be ready to beare with any of you.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Wife, you shall drinke a health to all the Cuckold-maker in Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You meane wrestlers sweet-heart; you are so taken with your Cornish Prentice. I tell yee gentlemen, hearing him talke the other day of the hugge, I wisht him to shew me what 'twas: the stiffe knave presently gives me a fall: but it was upon a soft bed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Otherwise there had beene danger.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Come sweet Mistris, the other dance.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Will you make one sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Alas faire Mistris, my grosse body wants
A mimick activenesse.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: But you can move sir?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Bestir your stumps a little sir. Are women such bug-bears, especially handsome ones? for I have been flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Well said Wife; to him Wife.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I durst undertake yet, had you one of us in a corner.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: How she instructs me! nay then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you be gone George?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: After him Wife, put him too't, and tickle him home.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Ile warrant husband Ile bring him into play. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: It seemes this gentleman loves not the company of women.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: At least wise tis pretended. Wer't a plot
To gull her husband, I should love it dearely.
Why did not I attempt it, that have had
More opportunities then ever made
Sinne fruitfull in the pleasure? If't be so,
The next share shall be mine. I love a wench
As well as he or any.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: T'other health, and then farewell,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mr. Stitchwell is your name?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: A Taylor in the Strand; and I am as good a man there as Deputy Tagg in the City, though he thinke himselfe an Aldermans fellow, and no Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You mind Cuckolds much: good sir remember your selfe.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: By your leave then; I must, and I will, I will and I must.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What must you sir?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Why, you may doe what you will; and I will doe what I list. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: The Taylor's paid.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: By your favor, 'tis a lye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
And his Wife too by this. Follow mee gentlemen,
and if hee prevent it not, wee'l share some pastime. Sweet, I'le returne presently. Exeunt men.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Can my chast thoughts within their spotles circuit
Retaine a good opinion of this gentleman,
Who gives free scope to his libidinous will
In actions that staine conscience?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Can my ills
Grow to a greater heighth? my honours danger
Runs equall with my persons.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: He hath courted
Almost beyond resistance, (had not goodnesse
Preserv'd me white) to sully me with lust;
And failing offer'd marriage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Can a Brother
Conster this place, disguise, and company
Lesse then a lapse from vertue in a Sister,
Who labour'd more to be good really,
Then ever hypocrite did to appeare so.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: I must not trust. Besides, mine eye hath seene
An object that delights it; and desire
Begins to burne my bosome with new flames
I yet ne're felt. 'Tis an ambitious love,
And must be check't. Why? sure my Birth's more noble:
My spirit argues it, which never yet
Harbour'd a common thought; but all above
The lownesse of my fortune. How now Mistris?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Distrest beyond recovery. 'Twas my brother;
Whose eye no sooner found me, but his lookes
Exprest a troubled soule: but when he heard
My tongue deny my selfe; what passions then
Possest him, may be thought.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Is he your Brother?
Feare not to be discover'd: I have plots
To circumvent him, and prepare his temper
For mild impressions. Enter Tapster.
Prethee Friend shew us a private roome.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: With convenience Mistris.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: For a retirement.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: This way Mistris. I smell the reward of a knaves office: howsoever sinne thrives by wickednesse. Frothfill'd Cans and over-reckonings will hardly raise a stock to set up with. Now will I informe the Gallants. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, forbeare. Is this a place to make ones husband a Cuckold in?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Let not such weake excuses rob my hopes
Of that delight, for whose enjoying
Danger and all that weaknesse can be frighted with—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, talke not to me of weaknesse. The servants of the house will suspect us presently.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Be expeditious then, we lose that time
Might make the pleasure fruitfull.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Indeed sir I durst ee'n venture to make him cuchold, might I be sure you would get a boy.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That's doubtles, sweet.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And shall he be like the father?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: As ever Citizens sonne was.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I meane my husband.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I am a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Kind sir, you even deserve it for your policie. But I am so affraid.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Mischiefe on these delayes.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Vexation racks me.
Prevented at the point of such a happinesse!

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Come Chuck and hold my head.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, hide your selfe:

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Happily, here's an empty tub. To them Stitch.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: My head akes Wife; where art chicken?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Here husband. You must presse upon womens retirement.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Oh my stomacke; 'tis very sick.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Emptie it in the fields then; let not the servants take notice you are such a sloven.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Why not in that rub?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Fie beast: defile a necessary implement of house-wifry? This 'tis to drink healths to Cuckolds. You might have beene one your selfe, were not I the honester woman; which is more then many of your neighbours can say for themselves.

div.head: The fifth Scoene.
div.stage: To them FRANKE, CHANGELOVE, IAMES, SAM, and a little after them a wench with a payle of water.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Wher's Mr. Stitchwell? Fie, give out man, and steale away.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Oh gentlemen my head, my head; oh gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Me thinks your forehead's swolne sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Truly no sir. There's no more then what hath beene ever since I was his wife; fifteene yeeres and upwards, a long time of barrennesse.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What the Divell make all these gentlemen in my Dames wash-house? Get yee up to your chambers with a vengeance.

div.stage: Powres the water into the tub.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I wonder where my friend is.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Hold, hold; I am drown'd.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: George, what made you there?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
Mischiefe on you sir: you have spoild mee a paile of conduit water cost mee many a weary step the
fetching; beside the falls my sweet-heart Slip gave me.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Alas good gentleman; he hid himselfe from my Wife, and see what's hapned.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Hell take your wife and you. Accursed women,
That in your curse made Man so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fye George, scold presently after your cucking.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Diogenes in dolio.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: And lamentation.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Come forth George: now the Comedie is ended, away with the disguise.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Women or divells,
Made faire to be destructions instrument.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You seeme to compassionat the mischance:

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.l: Good heart: but that he cannot endure a woman,
She should kisse him for amends.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thinke it would grieve any woman. I came hither for somthing else then to be rail'd at.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.l: Let's vexe him no more Gentlemen. Come wife,
He goe sleepe a little. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: There will be a safe opportunitie for me. I love this Cuckold-making.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Franke, though your selfe intend a reformation,
You might forbeare me: this was your owne plot.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why mine? I ne're had resolution yet
So stay'd, but I could alter it for pleasure:
Nor can I hate or envy it in others.
I am sorry George you should drinke water after your sweet-meats. To them Tapster.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Doe not abuse me lest I thinke revenge:
I am almost tempted to attempt it.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman hath withdrawne her selfe.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: What Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: Shee in the sattin gowne. You know my meaning sir, shee's as right—

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Thanks honest Robin. Here's for thee.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: I must thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: I'le take the first opportunity.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: The gentlewoman is retir'd sir.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: What gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: You know my meaning. Shee's as right—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Poxe on your Pandarising.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: How now sir? I wonder what quantity of maiden modesty went to your making up. Few gentlemen of your complexion would have beene angry with an honest Tapster for such intelligence.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: My Sister turn'd a common prostitute?
I must discover it.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: The gentlewoman's gone into another chamber Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: Shee in the sattin gowne. There's a bed: you know my meaning. Shee's as right—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are a rogue sirrah. kicks him.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: Good sir, what meane you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mutter that thought agen: I'le cut thy tongue out.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: And kill anon, anon sir. But cold rewards. Had none any better; Pandars would never purchase. Exit.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I'le take the Tapsters word, and trye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come gentlemen, let's up agen. By this time George your sorrow's drye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: And why should you thinke so Slip?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: If I finde them not, count me no wiser then an Apothecary, that lookt for Iewes eares on an old Pillory; When the dead wood bore none but Scriveners.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Enquire diligently, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I will sir, and arme my selfe like a country Iuror: I cannot hold out too fast till I have given up my verdict. Exit.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: My patience Sir hath hitherto made faire
The outside and appearance of that good
Your promise seem'd to meane me. Circumstance
Doth now instruct my feare, that this credulity
May be my danger. Trechery oft lurkes
In complements. Y'have sent so many poasts
Of undertakings, they out-ride performance.
And make me thinke your faire pretences ayme
At some intended ill; which my prevention
Must strive t'avert. Then good sir, leave me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Sir, though my outside's meane; I have a soule
Instructed in all dues belong to man.
I never yet mis-us'd a common action
With a prepar'd dissembling. My intents
Are fairer then your jealousie, which lives
But in the darknesse of your ignorance.
'Tis a blind humour, let discretion guid it:
That th'end of your owne good be not perverted
By ill receiving of the hopefull meanes
My freenesse offers.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: You have heard my story;
But why it should so stirre compassion
In any stranger, counsell cannot well
Remove the doubt.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Why Sir, I know a gentleman
Worthy in all things; but his crosser fortune
(On which mine had dependance as a servant)
Rob'd him at once of all those gifts she lent him;
Estate, life, wife; his infant-Issue left
To her blind pitty. Can I thinke you then,
Without some feeling, heare the sad relation
Of a misfortune, is so like to that,
As if the selfe same inauspicious starres To them Slip.
Were both their meanes. The newes sirrah.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Very bad Sir. My incredulous hostesse will not trust: therefore pray sir make hast; for without some supply
of drinke I faint in the halfe way of my message.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Hast found them?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Ther's hopes or so: I heard an inckling. The house swarmes with gallants; some of which have surely taken up Ciceley, paltry Baggage, she playes the Lady at least, and makes mincing faces like a countrey Bride at the upper end of the table.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.p: Pray Sir let's in: we may perhaps find them heere.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: O fate, unlesse thy guiding kinder prove,
Despaire kils all my hope, and ends my love. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Oh Cakes and Ale, if you your sweets denye,
Let Slip despairing in a halter die.

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p: FEare not Mistris any of their attempts in my house: you have your instructions and my ayde. Make use of any thing I owne for your honest ends, and if you need my person, I am ready in my barre at your call. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: We thanke you Mistris.
Why should you feare the execution
Of my desires? why are women subject
To that disease? or else hath nature chose it
To shew the difference? I was meant a man sure;
For I have Masculine resolutions,
Which no deluding spirits can abuse
With their mis-guiding; nor imperfect moone-light
Mock with false shadowes. Danger frights not me.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Doubt of my lov'd friends safety (without whom
My soules abilities are dead to use)
Hath numb'd the sense of action: I'm all passive.
Yet I haue heard from him relations
Of horrid battailes, and his persons danger;
When as the murdering Canons choak't the ayre
With their curl'd mists, their lowd noise ushering death
To his black triumph. A little custome made it
To be my pastime. Those were dangers past;
But these to come.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: You have a soldier sweet-heart,
And no more courage! what a race of Cowards
Would spring from that loves joyning? for Physitians
Say women have most right in the conception.
Were but our causes chang'd (our cases are)
I'de tell this brother all; and if his love
From a pretence of care deny'd me ayde,
I'de schoole him soundly. Come, come, you shal, tell
Your Brother that I love him.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Love my Brother?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Your Brother Mistris. If my beauty can
(Which ha's beene flatter'd for a taking one)
Win upon his desires, I'le soone worke him
To what you please. Nay, rather then the project
Should faile of a successe, he shall enjoy me;
But fairely.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Ayde me now discretion. Would you
Make mean agent to undoe my Brother;
And but for such meane ends?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Why gentlewoman,
Disparage not my low condition.
Perhaps misfortune meant it not my birth;
That might be noble as your owne, though boasted
From th'heraulds Catalogue of dead Ancestors.
My father oft hath told me when my fingers
Prest the Cowes dugges, and from their fulnesse drew
Aboundance of white streames, that Nature meant not
These limbs for labour. But this may appeare
The flattery of my selfe.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Into what maze
My dangers lead me! i'th middle ther's a Monster,
If I goe on, will ruine me: if back;
I want an Ariadnean Clue of policie
To be my guide.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: If you'l preserve your selfe
From a discovery, you must counterfeit
Some other passions; or clothe these in mirth.

div.head: The second Scoene.
To them IAMES, presently after GEORGE.
div.p: How now maide? why left you the doore open?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: 'Tis shut agen sweet Mistris. If it offend you, I will buy my pardon at your owne rate.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: What would you have sir?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: A little pleasure Sweete. Come, come, what's your price?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: You sure mistake me sir.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: As if I had not practis'd wenching sufficiently to understand a dissembled modesty: because I am a stranger, I'le come to your lodging when I know where 'tis. But say your price? halfe a crowne?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Have I found you gallant? I am dearer Sir; that's my maids rate. The truth is I have my Maiden-head yet, and have bargain'd with a gentleman below for it.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Let me have it; I'le double his reward.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: I love to be as good as my word. Sure sir hee'd kill you if he knew of your attempt. That's he sir. Knock.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: And my young valour dare not encounter him.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Your Citie-borne coward never make's fortunate whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Would I were safe.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Best hide your selfe in this sir.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: A handsome convenience. When hee's gone, release me.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Feare it not sir, but be sure you lie still. Open the dore maid; and doe you heare? get the key of the truncke.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What may this come to?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Pardon me faire one. My intrusion tends
To begg a happinesse; please you to crowne it
With your consent and welcome?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: What's in me
To grant, you shall command.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I take your word.
The pleasure of your bed. I will reward it
With a new gowne and angels; dally not
In any coy deniall.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Not in this place.
But if you please— whisper.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: New jealousie instructs.
My feare this woman's naught, and such a one
As sels her selfe to sinne. What fates conspire
To make me miserable?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: 'Tis a motion
Sutes with my liking. The paines will make the pleasure
More sweet in the enjoying.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Courting her!
George, 'tis not friendly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Mischiefe on suspition.
I've given you all the flattering commendations
That might confirme her love.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No more; I thanke thee.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I leave yee. Now to my practice of revenge,
And the delight it comprehends within it
Above Elizium. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Deare, when shall my love
Be happy in enjoying what it makes
The object of desire? Shall this faire morning
Be consecrate to Hymen?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Worthy Sir,
Such is the difference 'twixt your birth and fortune,
And my condition (whose inferiour ayme
Dare not be level'd higher then it's equalitie)
Makes (cowards pollicie,) feare, to be th'excuse
Of my delaye. For were you satisfide
With that which you call pleasure; and satietie
Had ta'ne the edge off, what's in me can whet
New appetite, and revive a dying love?
Your estimation branded with the infamy
Of a base choyce: taunts from the mouth of envy:
Aspersions to beget a killing jealousie.
And when you shall reflect—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Prethee no more
These needlesse doubts. I'm arm'd with preparations
For my resolves, that no assault can bitter.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Pardon me sir; there's ground of circumstance
To build a faith on, that your desires end
Is my enjoying for your senses pleasure.
Not the converse which love instructs the soule in.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why should false feares make such a bad construction?
Prethee no more.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: But I must search you throughly.
Y'are noble sir; and now I will unmaske
This false complexion of an hypocrite,
Which hitherto deluded your opinion
But with a shew of vertue. The truth is
My inclination's wanton; and this day
I meant to make a sale of that, for which
You have so fairely bid: my Maiden-head.
You see I'm fitted for it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What doe I heare?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: The gentleman that left me, is the Merchant.
A price is likewise set upon the ware.
The time and place of enterchange appointed.
The meanes: a porter in that trunke must carry me
Vnto his chamber: You seeme troubled Sir
At the relation.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis to trye me sure:
She cannot meane it. How my thoughts rebell
Against their guide?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Troth sir, I must confesse
Your person likes me better, and the love
You have profest deserves my gratitude.
Meete you this porter, and compell him with you;
You shall enjoy me first, and afterwards
When I set up the trade be still more welcome.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Should this be earnest. it would make me happy
Above mine owne desire; and should she mock me,
'Twere but returning to my first intents.
Some way I must enjoy her. Shall this practice
Give me those sweets have beene so long deny'd
With counterfeited modesty?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Be sure sir;
My Tutor in the Art left me instructions
To take the fairest offer.

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.l: My reward
Shall treble his. Be constant to my pleasure,
I'le keepe thee like a wife; and serve thy will
With full content.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: That as your liking pleaseth.
When you are weary, I'le but begg your bounty
For a new wardrobe to set up with.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How mans desire
Pursues contentment! 'tis the soule of action,
And the propounded reason of our life.
Yet as the choyce appeares, or grosse or excellent,
We flye not from th'injoying; but are chang'd
In our opinion either of the object,
Or of the meanes that workes it. Why should I
Alter a resolution? The contentment
Is still the same: and a farre easier meanes
Without that tye necessitates the will
To a sixt bounds. Besides, my credit's safe.
To keepe a Mistris youths excuse may serve;
But an inferiour match brands my posteritie,
If equall blood commixe not. Hence then scruple,
And all that frights saint conscience. sweet I welcome
The freenesse of your kind and loving promise
With as much joy, as can possesse a heart
Made joviall by th'effect of all it's wishes:
Be constant to it.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Be you confident;
I cannot be diverted from my purpose:
The end's too pleasant, Pray prepare your selfe;
The time drawes on.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And till my expectation
Ends in that full possession of delight,
Times wings are clipt. So farewell sweet till then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: And farewell base desires. May thy soule lust
Make thee still credulous, till abuse and shame
Teach thee amendment. What an Oratour
Is Sin? that paints it selfe with golden words
Of pleasure and delight; as if the soule
Had it's eternall being and full powers
But for the senses satisfaction:
And their enjoying it Creations end.
Now to our Comedie. Ha! fast asleepe!
This fits our purpose. Lock it fast.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Will not the feathers choake him?

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Hee's arm'd against mischances. Give it the Porter,
I must withdraw. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Now I perceive
Goodnesse guides all her actions: her minds brightnesse
Out-shines her outward beauty. But what use
Can my misfortune make of't? yes; th'example
Shall teach me how to counterfeit, if I
Can force my passion to it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Now wench, is all ready?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I have pack't her up in't, like a Bartholmew-babie in a boxe. I warrant you for hurting her.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis a good wench. I'le give thee a new gowne for it.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I thanke you sir. When you are weary of my mistris, and cast her off (as I know you must have change) you shall have my maiden-head at the same rate if you please: I'le keepe it for you.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis a bargaine.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: But two words to it. Pray sir use her nere the worse for my promise.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: The better. I'le turne her off within this fortnight, and send for thee.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Oh sir, 'tis not fit a servant should shift her Mistris trencher before the bones are cleane pick't. You have flesh enough to hold out a moneth.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: It shall be a moneth then?

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: Be carefull Porter of your carriage.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Married? that I am to a freemans widdow, and I weare the Citie-Armes by her first husbands copie.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: The Porter is deafe sure.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Pray sir let me aske you one question.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Quickly then.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: How many maiden-heads have you bought thus?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Some nineteene with thy mistrisses.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Pray sir, let mine make up the score: an even reckoning.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: It shall, it shall: heere's for thee Robin.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: The trunck is worth more sir, besides the feathers that are in it. But to doe you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Helpe him downe stayres with it.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: Heer's a Totenham-Court project translated over the water from Holland.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Farewell wench. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Adue good sir, with your faire bed-fellow that must bee.
Had I my Worthgood heere, this accident
Would straine my heart strings to a pitch of laughter,
And make my spleene dance. But his losse hath kill'd
All sense of joy. Ciceley returnes.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Now Mistris, what thinke you of it?
Have I not tane a course to punish lust?
At least wise with disgrace. Though custome calls
Those actions onely honest, that are glorious
In publique same; yet sometimes to dissemble
An ill that's not intended, when the end
Hath cleer'd it to opinion, it attaines
The greater praise.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Indeed, I must confesse
My feares possest me strongly you were noughe:
Nor is suspition grounded on due circumstance
To be accounted ill. But now my knowledge
Instructs me better to commend your vertue;
And steere mine owne course by the faire example
Of your discretion, were the like attempted
Vpon my chastity.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Now must I practise unaccustom'd impudence. By your leave gentle creatures: may I have my turne now for a little sport! Nay, nay, sweetheart, thou shalt serve: thy Mistris is too deare; and I am loth to pay over-much for repentance. 'Tis but changing offices: let her hold the dore for thee.

sp.speaker: Cice.
