sp.p: Pray sir, speake and meane civilly; you'l not be welcome else.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Good Lady light-heele; give your servant leave to practise the trade you have taught her. That such perfections as appeare in this woman should be sold to every base desire. Come wench, thy browne complexion pleaseth mee better then thy Mistrisses: thou dost not paint, and art the likelier to be wholsome.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Good gentleman, hee is jealous, and would circumvent her.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Heere's halfe a crowne wench; me thinks 'tis a faire rate. Ha! singer in the eye? Keepe thy teares for pennance in Bride well. Crye when money's offer'd thee?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Oh Brother.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ha! are you my Sister?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Your Sister Bellamie.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Why shee's in the Countrey at mine Vncles,
Teaching her hand some neat industrious practice;
Or painting with her needle the rare forme
Of some choyce flower; to her busie servant
Discoursing Moralls; or perhaps at prayers,
Or meditation: these were her exercises;
Not prostitution. What an impudence
Is this imposture?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Temper your anger brother,
For it appeares i'th wrincles of your brow.
And let not passion burne your jealous feares
With an intemperate heat. I have a story
You'l pitty, though all naturall affection
Were quite extinguisht.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Then you are my Sister?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Dissemble not those doubts; but heare me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Noe.
I'm deafe to all excuse. 'Tis too apparant.
Possesse me vertuous rage; make me the instrument
Of a religious justice.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Guard me innocence.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Oh that the knowing soule, which can distinguish
It selfe and powers; should yeeld her government
To the lascivious appetite of sense:
And under such a base subjection
Ruine her noble parts. True estimation
Is grounded on the actions of the minde:
And to determine bravely, well as honestly,
Must be the last, and most refin'd digestion
Of a high flying nature. Such should hers be.
She wanted not th'instruction, nor example
Of worthy Parents, that honour is the most
Essentiall part of life, and valewd 'bove it.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Good gentleman, hee's troubled.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Oh hypocrisie,
Thy painted showes must likewise mock our judgments
Into an apt credulitie, that makes
Bad worse by the dissembling. Had shee wanted
Or meanes of power or fortune to discover
This inclination; like the Serpent numb'd
With a long rigidnesse, forbeare's to sting
His warmers bosome, not because he hath not
A poyson; but because the force thereof
Is feebled by the cold.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: You seeme disturb'd sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: who'l ever trust devotion, or believe
That any zeale is earnest? I should rather
Have call'd an Eremite hypocrite: or suspected
Th'austerities of an Anchorite to be
But for vaine-glory or a common fame,
Then her appearing goodnesse. Fury prompts me
To a black act. 'Tis well I have no sword.
But may she not survive her first repentance;
Which shame or punishment shall teach her quickly.
Lustfull insatiate whore. Could not a husband
Have coold your bloud?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: You need no other weapon, she sownes.
Those words have kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Ay me, what have you done sir? helpe, helpe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If it be earnest, cur'd a wounded fame.
My reputation would have bled a little,
Had she liv'd longer infamous: her death
May lose the memory of her dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: Good gentlewoman she faints. Helpe, helpe.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The cry came from this Chamber.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'Sfoot sir, 'tis Mistris Ciceley, and Ciceley Mistris. Ha, ha, sir; did you put her to the squeake? I'le put you—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Hold sirrah.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: Looke up my love: ha! What malicious chance
Begets this new prevention of our happines?
Oh let our soules together climbe the height
Of their eternitie; if fate denies
Other enjoying.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: 'Tis my Worthgoods voyce.
That Orphean Musicke charmes my senses backe
From the darke shades of their privation.
Welcome againe: I never more will lose thee.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What are you sir, that seeme thus tender of her?

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: I give no answer to uncivill questions
With calmer words. And yet I scorne to strike,
Vnlesse I saw some armour for resistance.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: This is my Husband Brother, farre as vowes
Can joyne us, till Church-ceremony hath
Confirm'd it stronger.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: Hee your Brother sweet?
His pardon first; then leave I may embrace
His worthy love.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis not your complement
Can win upon me. If your worth deserves
My Sisters love (I hope my Vncles care
Hath well examin'd it) freely enjoy
What you desire: But my opinion is
Scarce settled yet. You seeme a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: And am one: that was giv'n me in my birth.
If not, my sword hath purchas'd it.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: With leave
I would relate the accident to satisfie
Your curious love; which makes you doubt that ill
Ne're stain'd a thought in her: and for my selfe,
My life's untouch'd by envy.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Gentle sir,
Let my perswasion worke upon your temper;
And make it pliable to forgoe all jealousie,
And misconstruction. Something is reserv'd
In mine owne knowledge, shall disperse those clouds
That muffle error in their misty rowles;
And makes it blind in all things but in mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If Bellamie be vertuous, shee's my Sister;
And shall not lose that interest.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Now Ciceley,
'Tis time that you disrobe.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: By no meanes father.
My part's not ended yet.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Please her accept
Th'exchange as my thanks gift; since to her care
And full discretion I must attribute
My safety. Something's now in action,
By her begun from an ingenious practice,
Will make the end more comicke.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: But 'twill turne
To a sad Tragedy, if I enjoy not
This worthy gentleman.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: A larger roome
Were more convenient. Please you sir the house
Is well accommodated.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.l: What's more to be expected
Can crosse or crowne our loves with new events? Exe.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Goe your wayes and quarrell no more, lest I bee stickler with this terrible Embleme of a Butchers cruelty. Exit.

div.head: The seventh Scoene.
div.stage: Enter CHANGELOVE, WIFE; STITCHWELI in a Chayre asleepe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The effects of drinking, Mr. Changelove: his head should be troubled with something else, were he rul'd by me. But he cares not for my counsell, nor mee. I could eene curse mine own kindnes, that am ready still to make more of him then he doth of me.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Why doe you not then—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What sir? I warrant you meane make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: That's a grosse construction. Give a friend leave to do you a pleasure, or so. The truth is Mistris I love you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You were ever kind Mr. Changelove.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.l: And would your freenes give me leave t'enjoy
Those sweets, although forbidden, 'twould be a happines
'Bove my desire. Be assur'd my secrecie
Is firme as night and locks.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Secresie, Mr. Changelove? I would have you know I will be open to all the world. I'le doe no more in the darke, then in this very place, were my husbands eyes open.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Here then. He sleeps securely, never dreaming Of any foreheads arming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Fie Mr. Changelove, you are such a tempter. Pray set heare many a woman would not hold out so long.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Consent then sweet; wee'l to it.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Ware hornes there.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Mischiefe, what noise hath wak't him?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: An infirmitie hee hath to talke in's sleepe. Nay I assure you hee will rise sometimes and doe the office of a waking man in his dreame, and not know of it in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Rome for one of the headmen in his Parish: a monster of his wifes making.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Wicked man; hee dreames now that I would make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: Send it be no counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: And have I tane you sir Lancelot? would you be billing with my Guinever?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Helpe me Mistris Stitchwell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Take it patiently Sir: his fit will bee over presently.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: For this attempt King Arthur doth here degrade thee from a Knight of his round Table, to bee a Squire of his Wifes body. So conduct me to her bed; where I will beget a race of warriours shall cage thy great Turkship againe, and restore Constantinople to the Emperour.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: You mistake: oh. My Perriwig is not a Turbant.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Peace follows victory, let us now to rest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray sir, forgive him: I dare undertake hee'l be sorry for it when he wakes. If any thing I can may make amends.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Prove his dreame true. When the smart's over I shall forget it. Enter Tapster.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: A quest of inquiry is sent all the house over to looke you Mistris. The gentlewomans maid was in a swound: they wanted your assistance.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Who wants assistance? who breaks the Kings peace? fetch me my Constables staffe.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: Hee'l dreame againe: had I best stay?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now drunkard, are you recoverd yet?

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Wife and Mr. Changelove, wheres the company?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Gone, being weary of such a sot as you make your selfe. Pretend a walke for health and recreation, to bee drunke so early? I had done well to have served you in your kinde: here were gentlemen enough that would have brought me home; and some not farre off that used me kindly, whilst you snorted to fright fleas, and dream't perhaps some wickednesse of me.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Prethee peace sweet wife: Ile mend all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I promise you, you shall never mend me, till you doe better your selfe.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: I'le buy my pardon for it with a new gowne, and a journey into the Countrey next vacation.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You know Iohn I am easie to be wrought upon.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Will you discharge the reckoning Mr. Changelove?

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: Not willingly: I doe not love it. No revenge upon this dreaming tyrant over unpaid for gallantry? A protection to defraud him is long since provided. What is your reckoning, Robin?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Nine and three-pence sir.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: The particulars.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: Cakes two shillings. Ale as much. A quart of mortify'd Claret eight pence. Stewd pruins twelve pence.

sp.speaker: Change.
sp.p: They were deare.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Truely, they cost a penny the pound of the one-handed Coster-monger, out of his wifes fish-basket. A quart of Creame, twelve-pence.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: That's too excessive.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.p: Not if you consider how many Carriers egges miscarried in the making of it; and the charge of Ising-glasse and other ingredients to cremifie the soure milke.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: All this is but a Noble.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Pray marke me sir, I'le make it more. Twelve-pence Sugar. You had bread sir.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: And we had drinke sir.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: 'Tis granted sir. A pound of sausedges, and other things, nine shillings and three-pence. Our Barre never erres.

sp.speaker: Chang.
sp.p: I'le talke with your Mistris. You know my meaning Robin. steales away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh the extortion of Tottenham-Court!

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: No matter Wife: kinde Mr. Changelove will pay for all. Ha! where is hee?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: Gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Then give me my Cloake.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: The reckoning first Sir.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: How! must Taylors pay Gallants reckonings?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sure husband, he intends this a satisfaction for his beating.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: Have you such tricks? No great matter: 'tis but adding it to his bill in my debt-booke, and presently arresting him with a fat Martiallist. Here sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Y'are welcome Sir. Some profit comes from hence:
I have ore-reckon'd one and twenty-pence. Exeunt.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter GEORGE and PORTER with the Trunck, presently after them VNCLE, SERVANT and TENANTS.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: A Heavy burthen I assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: That's strange: a light Wench, and feathers.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: You say true Sir; 'tis enough to break a mans back.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: His mistake hits upon truth. Rest thee Porter.
Oh this plots quaintnesse: witty luxury,
How it acutes invention, and makes pregnant
Even barren faculties to beget new issues
Of rare conceipt. But my credulity
Was rash and sodaine. If she hath abus'd it,
And mockt my hopes of pleasure, what revenge
Can give me satisfaction? Here's the key,
Though late these doubts arise, I greatly long
To have mine eye resolve them. Company,
Forbeare a little then, and rest thee Porter.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: 'Tis a faire circumstance, and may confirme
My first suspition. Where found you the Horses?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: In the high way neere yonder houses. The place is called TOTENHAN-COURT.

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p: Our intelligence hath something Landlord.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: What's That?

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p: The truth is being weary—

sp.speaker: 2 Neig.
sp.p: Old men Landlord, old men. Labour agrees worse with us then wrangling with a leane Parson that hath a fat Benefice.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Pray 'interrupt him not: Forwards Neighbour.

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p:
At a house yonder we prevail'd to be let in:
where the little time that remain'd 'till morning we slept soundly.

sp.speaker: 2 Neig.
sp.p: And dreamt we were in Cranborne Church at a drowsie Sermon.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: On good Neighbour.

sp.speaker: 1 Neig.
sp.p: Day no sooner peept, but noyse wak't us. The house was presently full of Gallants with Musicke, and to dauncing they went. We askt the reason, they of the house told us 'twas customary for Gentlemen to have early revels and rendevous there. At length we heard one speake of a Gentlewoman in a sitten gowne: which we conceiving to be Mistres Bellamie, made haste to London to your Son to informe your worship.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Oh my curst fate; they have prevented sure.
My care, by zeale and nature so instructed
To tender her good, that I have not left
Counsaile or threats unurg'd to perfect it.
They are questionlesse matryed.

sp.speaker: 2 Neig.
sp.p: Might I advise your worship then let them alone 'till night: when they are in bed together, they are the likelier to be catcht napping.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: My Nephew's gone abroad too. Is't the custome
Of Students that pretend a love to Learning
And noble Sciences, to make the morning
Their time of recreation? Or have they
Had correspondence, and his friendly ayd
Is in the plot! Yon Porter may perhaps
Informe us something.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: If these question the Porter, I must answer for him.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Good speed friend. Didst see a Gentleman and a Gentlewoman abroad in the Fields?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Betwixt nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He meanes the clock: his hearing is surely imperfect.
Didst see a Gentlewoman in a satten gowne?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a heavy burthen: I fetcht it from TOTENHAM-COURT.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Didst see a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman in a Trunck of Feathers! that were very pretty.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Oh villaine.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman at TOTENHAM-COURT!

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I saw many there Sir, and one in satten: but they are all upon parting.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: I thanke you Sir. Come let's hasten. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: What may this be! It hath begot new jealousies.

div.head: The second Scoene.
To them FRANKE.
div.l: And here's new mischiefe. Hath the Devill policie
To prevent ill? There's no avoyding him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis he: h'hath spide me; and his feares deject him.
Sweet constancie, how I could blame the good
Thy kindnesse meanes me, that hadst rather lose
Thine owne white purity, then staine my credit
With spots time cannot wash out. Doubly happy
Shall I be in enjoying her, and punishing
A trecherous friend.
George, how long have you converst with the Frock-trade?
I thought the smock had bin your chiefe delight.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: The Porter waits upon me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With stuffing for your bed.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: A light commodity I bought at Totenham-Court. Didst ever thinke I should have been so thrifty to buy feathers at the best hand? When I have us'd them throughly, there are Suburb Upholsters will give me my money agen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Me thinks they are very heavy.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Let them alone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Have not you stolne mine Hostes great brasse Pot she boyled old marrow-bones in, for the fat to make her
Cakes with when Butter is scarce? Porter you shall carry it along with me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Prethee goe backe to thy milke Mayde.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Dost thou deride me? Nay then Porter up with it, or here's a goud to force you, and let out some of your Goats blood.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Thou dar'st not strike a friend basely.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Friendship is canceld.
Th'ast broke the league that knit over our outward love:
For in consent of ill Love's never solid.
Hadst not abus'd that love with foule intents:
I would have thankt thy paines, which she contriv'd
Onely for me t'enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Is't even so!
You shall heare from me Franke. Come hither Porter,
She hath legs to walke with you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But that I thinke disgrace a punishment
Worthy the guilt, this instant houre should give
The wrongs thou didst intend a satisfaction.
I must be bold sweet: mine are no Porters shoulders.
A Coach waits not farre off.

div.head: The third Scoene.
To them CHANGELOVE, STITCHWELL, WIFE.
div.p: Lie still a little, here's company.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Let me ruminate.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: I payd the reckoning Mr Changelove, and am sorry for it, I meane the wrong I did you.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: 'Twas no offence: or had it; you have satisfi'd.
I love the memory of it. 'Twill be a Story
To greet a ring of friends with: next I meete
Shall have it all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
It may passe indeed for a merry one by a good
fire in Winter, which I love dearely.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: A good fire Mistresse Stitchwell is Winters artificiall Sun, that renewes Summer within doores. I love it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: With two or three good companions, and a gossips feast.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: That's very right. Society is the use
Of mans best ornaments. Speech and discourse
Are reasons messengers, that carry errands
From one soule to another. I confesse
I love good company.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: 'Tis a good exercise to rise in a frosty morning, and kill Birds.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: You say well Sir, We that have youthfull blood,
That capers in our veines, and swels their concaves
With active warmth, should be inur'd to hardnesse.
Tis healthfull, and I love it.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I have it. Doe you know these Franke?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mischiefe, I must prevent them.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: You may if please you, suffer the Porter to passe, and stay yourselfe. Credit is pretious: let me enjoy my sport, yours may be preserv'd. Otherwise your trull and you shall both suffer. I am desperately resolute, and will reveale all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I as desperate. Up with it Porter.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Any thing: will you suffer this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Nay then Franke. Draw▪ and a passe or two.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Helpe helpe.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: If he be gone sweet heart, let me out. I am almost stifled. They take him out of the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Whence that voyce?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The Gentlemen that were in our company! Let us prevent them. Be not afraid Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Alas I cannot endure such naked weapons.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: What will this come to?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: I beseech ye Gentlemen kill me not, I have beene sufficiently mortified; and I beleeve you may smell, the effects of my feare.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Is this the lovely piece, for whose enjoying
I have attempted what by ill successe
Makes me ridiculous: yet I swell with laughter
To thinke how finely she hath gull'd us both,
And mockt our easie trust.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray' Sir how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: I thinke upon that Porters shoulders.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But how into this Trunk?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Ile tell you sir. Bargaining for a little sport with the Gentlewoman, whom I thought to be a wanton, she possest me with scare, (to which cowardize is alwaies apt, and I must acknowledge in my selfe) that a Gentleman (one of you two I take it) had dealt with her for her Mayden-head, and that shee expected him. He came: and I fearing lust as well as love would brooke no rivall, made use of this for my safety. Where being heavy headed with Ale, I have slept till your noyse wak't me.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.p: An excellent conceit; how like you it Wife? This Gentleman cannot endure the company of Women.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I knew before he did but dissemble: that made me so desirous to try him. There was a Tub at Totenham; you I now the successe of it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: I ever thought Mistresse Stitchwell that was your owne plot; and I love you dearely for it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Love me Mr Changelove? Take heed my Husband doe not dreame of it.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.p: That was her plot too. Now doe I see, some Women can counterfeit wickednesse, aswell as many dissemble honesty. Come Sir, let you and I drowne the memory of our disasters in a cup of Sack. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You see gallants what successe attends your enterprises.
Henceforth account not every City Wife
Wanton, that onely loves a merry life.

sp.speaker: Stit.
sp.l: And here's a double comfort; being wedded,
Shee's neither false, nor am I jealous headed. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Accurst credulity. Could not those doubts
I shapt my jealousie, preserve my first,
And noble resolution I Had I urg'd it
With greater zeale, she must have forc't her reason
To understand m'intention without practise
Of farther tryall. Now she's lost for ever;
Though I should with submission and repentance
Beg reconciliation with her thoughts,
(Whose purity cannot endure to mixe
With mine that were so foule) she would reject it.
Ile back, and try. Lustfull affections hence.
My Lov's new cloth'd in vertuous innocence. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Frank We are friends: since we have shar'd disgrace,
We kill all malice. Henceforth I shall strive
To live more chaste. Lust is a gilded pill,
Which sinfull nature doth prescribe desire.
It mocks the sence with pleasure; but at last
The shining outside leaves a bitter tast. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: But prethee tell me, what's her condition?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Womanish. She'l cry when shee's angry; laugh when she's tickled, and be sick when she cannot have her owne will.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I meane her calling.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: She is call'd Cicily.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Her profession then.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Not very honest, and yet very honest. She cheats all the world that thinks she is wanton: but you may find by the late stories, that neither your Aunts nor Cousins can keep their legs so close.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Here's money for thee.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
You are as bountifull as a new made Knight, that
courts a City Widdow by Atturney for the officers fees.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Prethee tell me how was she borne?

sp.speaker: Slip
sp.p: You had b●d ask the Midwife.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: This fellow trifles. Is the Keeper thy Master her owne Father?

sp.speaker: Slip
sp.p: Should you conjure the Devill into her dead Mother, he might chance to tell you flye.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is she a Gentlewoman or not?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: She is, and she is not. She is a Gentlewoman as she loves pride: which makes Gentlewomen apt to fall; especially those of the wayting forme. Then she is no Gentlewoman because— because—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Prithee no more.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: 'Tis well you interrupted me, for I had no reason: But Sir I will bring her to the barre of your presence, where she may answere for her selfe, whilst I convert your bounty into wholesome nourishment from a black Pot, and have a bout with mine own sweet Turnup.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Mine eye nere saw with aptnesse to desire
That beauty could enthrall m'unbounded thoughts
With passionate affection. Yet this piece
Is absolute, and such as cannot choose
But have a glorious mind. Love is a cement
That joynes not earthly parts above, but workes
Upon th'eternall substance, making one
Of two agreeing soules. Were she borne nobly,
(As surely such perfections cannot be
The issue of base parents) so that infamie
Might not succeed, here would I fixe my choyce.
Besides she's vertuous, and her education
Beseeming greatnesse: her discourse; pure language;
Iudgement, and full behaviour argue it.

div.head: The fifth Scoene.
To him, CICELEY.
div.l: Shee's come. How like an Angell, as if sent
On some celestiall message to the soule
Of a departing Saint. White innocence
Is in each looke and feature, as all goodnesse
Had built their mansion in her. Welcome faire one,
I hope my pardon's seal'd for thus presuming
On what you might call rudenesse.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: You have shapt
Needlesse apologie to excuse a guilt,
When none appeares. I owe much to your vertue
It doth command my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Which are so glorious,
I must admire the actions that expresse them.
I hope your judgement doth not call it ill,
That my intemperate anger being grownded
On vertuous suspition, did transport me
Beyond a moderate passion. I am satisfi'de.
Your innocence hath cleer'd my jealousie;
Which was I know instruction to my sister,
And th'onely working meanes that kept her safe.
The Gentleman she loves I finde is worthy:
Though his estate through the improvidence
Of a free minded Father, low enough.
My Vncle may repaire it: she hath hopes
T'inherite all. And trust me did I love
Where I perceiv'd desert, no inequalitie
Of fortunes blind additions, birth or state,
Should interpose a let to my enjoying.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis a noble resolution,
Pure love's a vertue Nature onely teacheth;
And's borne with generous Spirits that distinguish
The object truely; sleighting those respects
That worke on grosser minds.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How shee instructs me
In resolution? Fairest I shall use
None other circumstance, or paint a passion
My reasons eye allowes: though first my sense
Convey'd the knowledge of your outward forme,
And full perfections, which must needs conteine
A richer inside. Vertue seldome dwells
But in a glorious frame. I love your goodnesse:
For that your beauty. In my new borne wishes
I have determin'd you the partner
Of all that's mine. My state's not very meane:
If 'twere, zeale should supply; I'de strive to merit
The free gift of your selfe, and in exchange
Returne my selfe.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Sir, I could answere you
With your owne wordes: for I presume your thoughts
Are noble like your selfe; unmixt with flatt'ry,
Courtships infection; and the poysonous breath
That many times doth make pure love suspected
Whether it be found or plaster'd to deceive
Our credulous weaknesse, till it hath possest us
With some foule leprosie. Your handmaid yeelds
To what agrees with honour; if the meannesse
Of her condition may presume to call
Her honest credit so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How you doe blesse me
As suddainly as my desires could shape
A meanes to worke it? Instantly the Church
Shall seale the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Would not you deliberate
Those acts are lasting, and concerne the being
Of all your after life?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis heavens providence
That hath dispos'd it. Thus I seale my vowes

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: And here are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My Vncle! what makes he here? new doubts arise.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: See, see; my thoughts were prophesie: both here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You are welcome to Totenham Court Uncle.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: But you'r ill come Cosen. I had thought.
Your judgement had beene stronger than to aid
A foolish Sister with your fond indulgence
In her undoing. She may hide her face
My rage distracts me, and I know not how
To frame th'induction.

sp.speaker: 1. Neigh.
sp.p: Why sir, this is not Mistris Bellamie but another in her clothes.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: How's that knave? hay day wife how came you by these? where

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.p: I am your Neece.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: You my Neece?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Shee's my Wife, Vncle.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Yet more plots I sure the Parson of 〈◊〉 has beene here.

sp.speaker: 1. Ten.
sp.p: Indeed I have heard he is a notable joyner.

sp.speaker: 2. Ten.
sp.l: And Totenham-Court Ale pays him store of tythe.
It causeth questionlesse much unlawfull coupling.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Pray where's your Sister? I'le not fright her
With many threats, but mildly worke her reason
To understand her errors; and prevent
Her ruine with disswasions. Coss shee's lost:
My love and care made uselesse.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is shee married Sir?

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Yea; that's my greatest feare, shee's past recov'ry,
Woman, what ere you are, you have some hand in't:
These were her clothes.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Let her selfe satisfie,
if passion hath not made you too uncapable.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Alas mine Vncle.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Killing spectacle.
Come from his armes: if any force restraine thee
But thine owne freenesse (which I most doe feare)
I will reveng't with lawes extremitie.
Come from his armes I say.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Vncle I owe
You many duties. One from natures precepts;
And morrall gratitude for your great love
Instructs me in another: but necessitie
In this compels a vertuous disobedience.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Girle hee's a begger. He had a prodigall father
That spent all ere he dyed: his whole estate
Depends but on the love of a rich Vncle;
And that's incertaine.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: Pray upbraid me not
With a dead mans misfortune. I have beene
A soldier, and perhaps am apt to anger.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Threaten your fill Sir, so my Neece forsake you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Kinde Vncle, call not poverty a sin.
Wealth's but the glosse and outside of desert.
And for my Sister, since she loves this Gentleman,
Shee hath some portion left her; your estate
Would be a faire addition: but the loves
Of Vncles are uncertaine. The truth is,
I love this maid: shee's but this Keepers daughter;
Yet I would marry her, please her good Father
To be consenting.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Blessings unexpected.
If she be willing. Shee's a poore girle Sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Shee's richer then the Indies.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: Shall mine age
Be curs'd to this misfortune. Ile build hospitals:
Where wooden legs and lazy hypocrites
Shall be mine heyres.

sp.speaker: 2 Ten.
sp.p: And the Divell your Executor.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.l: They scorne my easinesse.
I should have rag'd, and from a furious an
Sent threats, not calme intreaties.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: That would likewise
Have beene as uselesse. I conceive such joy
At these events, they almost have confounded
My preparations to begin the Story
Reserv'd to crowne all. First doe you imbrace
A naturall Sister.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: Mine owne Sister, sir,
Suppos'd to have dy'd an infant!

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: I still thought it
By an instinct.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: This is Cicilia Worthgood,
Whom my Wife nurst when both your Parents dy'd.
I have beene carefull of her education
Well as her person; though my love conceal'd
The knowledge of her selfe still from her self.
Least I should lose her: being th'onely comfort
I wisht from providence: Such was the duty
With which I honour'd your dead Auncestors
That brought me up.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Sir, this concernes not me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: It doth your Nephew, to whose loves imbrace
I next commend her, and a portion too.
She shall inherit somthing that hath beene
Stor'd from my care; nor hath her industry
Wanted a share.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: Still let me call you Father;
Whose love deserves it for my preservation,
And after being.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: What a knot of fortunes
Is here unty'd. Oh let me weare you ever
Vpon my heart with these. Enter Servant hastily.
Mine Vncles servant! What new accident?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Oh Sir, never was endeavour so tir'd. But I am glad I have found you. Your Vncle's dead, and hath made you his heyre.

sp.speaker: Vnc.
sp.p: Ha, ha! is't come about! nay then; are you married neece? if not, about it presently whilst 'tis morning. Thou shalt be mine heire likewise: love him; lye with him; Get boyes, and any thing now; you have my consent.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: And now I owe you duty.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: With what impudence
Shall I apparell my prepar'd excuse,
To make it passe? What meane so many people?
I am return'd to chide your cruell practice,
That mock't my vertue into wicked frailty,
And an abus'd beliefe. I am your convert;
And come with more then sorrow, satisfaction.
Let not the memory of my past errors
Pervert your thoughts into a worse opinion
Of my reclaiming, then if ill intents
Had nere exprest themselves.

sp.speaker: Wort.
sp.l: What meanes that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Hee's one of those that— whisper.

sp.speaker: Cice.
sp.l: If you'l have my Maidenhead,
A Husbands leave is light.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: As your Commodity:
How did you like it Sir? Enter Host.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: They will abuse me
Into a madnesse. Farewell vertuous Maid,
And blesse his bed deserves thee. Here I banish
All after-thoughts of Women; but t'admire
The goodnesse makes them perfect; since such were
Added to be mans onely comfort here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Most opportunely Widdow. I have sollicited long; and if you will now consent, let's beare these company.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: Why then to Pancras: each with his lov'd consort
And make it Holiday at Totenham-Court.

div.head: The EPILOGVE by the HOSTESSE.
div.l: AGaine y'are welcome. There's no more to pay.
But your kind liking. Tapster take away
If you deny't, as due for such meane Cheere;
And say your first paid reckoning was too deare,
I begge it as a bounty. If I winne
Your kinde commends, 'twill bring more custom in:
When others fill'd Roomes with neglect disdain ye
My little House (with thanks) shall entertain ye.
And if such Guests would dayly make it shine.
Our POET should no more drinke Ale but Wine.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.

note.label: c3cxk-003-b-1380
note.seg: . But heere is no such Satyre : nor is't
Abuse should bee the exercise of Wit . To

note.label: c3cxk-004-a-0300
note.seg: CICELEY . Sister to Worth-good , but

note.label: c3cxk-005-a-0080
note.seg: But when will it be
? the light hath comfort . 〈…〉 senses being

note.label: c3cxk-005-a-0130
note.seg: But when will it be day ? the light hath
. 〈…〉 senses being lost , The l●st are lesse

note.label: c3cxk-005-a-0160
note.seg: it be day ? the light hath comfort . 〈…〉
being lost , The l●st are lesse delighted
